comments.commentBody: The world is changing faster than your neolithic perspective allows. I'm no fan of Trudeau, but I am less of one of Harper. In fact, your main point that he "insulated" Canada from economic crisis is completely false. He was actually in the process of implementing deregulation and it was sheer luck that we weren't screwed along with the rest of the world who had already done so. It was the previous Liberal governments that had enacted the legislation that actually created our "insulation". Harper was HORRIBLE on so many levels it is hard to imagine a worse prime minister for Canada. The best thing he did was show Canadians the weaknesses of their electoral system that would allow a cretin like him to manipulate the gullible and fearful minority to give him a majority. http://theteteatete.org/2015/05/04/how-and-why-stephen-harper-is-a-bad-e...

John Townsend - Mexico
In Memoriam - October 23, 1983 - 241 USA service personnel (220 Marines) killed by truck bombing - Beirut, Lebanon - President Reagan was not blamed. It is bittersweet these fine brave Americans are not honored or remembered by national media lest they too become politicized.

The alleged purpose of the hearings is to find ways to improve security for our embassies and consulates and prevent a Benghazi from happening again. What do Clinton's emails have to do with that objective?
Calf tipping is real enough.  I see it every time I go to a rodeo where it leads to calf roping.  If the tipper is big enough and the cow is small enough, I'd say, yes it's possible.

She's explained that a number of times. OF COURSE she knew she was using her own private server, but she would regularly copy emails to staff with .gov addresses assuming they would automatically be archived from there. As it turned out, most were but some weren't. SO, I do believe her when she says she was surprised to find that a number of them weren't on the fed system. Her story makes perfect sense to me, especially since I came to email at about the same age, and about the same time, that she did; it's not as simple and straightforward as you're trying to make it sound in order to impugn her.

Trump and Carson "clean?" OMG, one is a comic bloviator with no political chops, and the other is a bigoted pretender (ditto about the chops). The Sisyphean task is that which the Republican Party now faces. They have a long trek uphill, and the weight of their missteps and misattunement keeps crashing down on them. Hard to make it back up, and probably won't. Not with this bunch.
That rule doesn't apply on NYT when BACK is part of a phrase.

"Back" twice in the same puzzle?
Gone are the days of professional setting, I guess.

and Elke
MTF- you knew you'd get my reco for Rosalind Franklin. Good that her pictures were not dismissed as just OPART.

She "stood her ground" on what, exactly? That her private server wasn't intentionally hidden from investigators? That she knew her emails were all offsite while she was claiming to have complied with information requests? That she hasn't been withholding key emails from investigators? The Benghazi Committee received over a thousand pages of Ambassador Stevens' emails just 2 days before this hearing.

Flowers for Mrs. Clinton, indeed.

Give it up, ACCNY, this fool and average American wants a President. Is it too much to ask of us not to pursue and court one of these weak bulbs in the chandeliers who wants us to see the light and put an end of any hope of restoring my Country, the Land of the Brave, to a state of freedom? I want substance, not shallowness, a political figure, tried and trued.

This is not the time to fool around with emails and broken servers, a matter of grave national security to the Nation. Hillary Clinton stood ground under pressure with grace and conviction.

If this uneducated secretary can do anything to help in her campaign for the Presidency, it will be a privilege and an honor to serve her and my Country because she has woken me up to the importance of our vision and the next generation for our future.

Thank you, Mrs. Clinton, for giving us some hope and a sense of passion. You have brought to my mind an old song by the musician, Bob Marley, controversial as he was for his time: 'Get up, Stand up', remaining by your side.

Witnessing a dark moment in contemporary history, hang down your head, America, and cry. Mrs. Hillary Clinton stood her ground, and it is this Benghazi Mob who stands naked and exposed to our eyes. Ill-intentioned, cruel measures and an exposure of the lost of humanity.

In the early 60s a social psychologist, Stanley Milgram, conducted an infamous experiment at Yale of how the Genocide could happen by pitting interrogating students against their victims, and this is what I saw today, a little diminished in the heart and soul.

Flowers for Mrs. Clinton who was able to make this American sit up, stand up and feel strong again in the face of this nest of political snakes.

Stephen Harper had to go. Frankly, this reader cannot think of a SINGLE notable achievement by Harper that benefited Canada in the long run. People - including him of course - claim that he reduced deficit. But at what cost? He ignored rotting infrastructure, for example.

Also, reducing expense is one; but what did he do about revenue? What single notable strategic decision he made to reduce Canada's over-reliance on natural resources? What single significant thing did he do to prepare Canada to exploit alternative energy technology?

He doggedly and unashamedly pursued fossil fuel. He TOTALLY and arrogantly disregarded alternative energy sources. He took Canada out of Kyoto protocol.

Before him Canada was always considered to be a mediator in international situations. Canada's role as a peacemaker was well known. In mid-east he single-handedly made Canada distrustful to others because of one-sided support for Israel.

However and in spite of all his flaws, he was at least partially correct in his stand against niqab or burqa (NOT to be confused with hijab). However, it is not what he did but how he did that made a difference in his handling of Muslim Canadians. For example, he fought tooth and nail to keep the Canadian prisoner Omar Khadr in Guantanamo when most other western countries repatriated their own citizens. He then fought against releasing him EVEN though the courts clearly sided with Omar Khadr.

So when it comes to Stephen Harper, good riddance.
The Republicans look like cheap bullies after eleven hours. Trey Gowdy's entire plan seems to be a Perry Mason move where the heckled witness breaks down and confesses everything.
One new thing was the revelation that Hillary knew the video narrative was a lie.

Yeah it was witch hunt, but she's also at fault caused she stirred witch's brew with that private email server. I was a longtime Hillary supporter. Now I'm hoping for a draft Biden movement. I give her credit for keeping her cool during the hearing; it was a GOP fail.
Jesse, it sounds as if you have been drinking too much of the Republican Kool Aid down here.

Grouch, Point by point:

Canadians rejected Harper's use of an article of clothing as a divisive and hateful diversion from real discourse on real topics. They resented the waste of money and time that the Harper regime spent fighting it in the courts.

When you have 3 parties with almost equal base support, none will get an absolute majority. There was a massive repudiation of the Harper regime, but not necessarily a rejection of all conservative thought. The fact is that the Harper regime was not particularly conservative as Canadians understand it. In response many Canadians voted strategically for the candidate in their riding that had the best chance of defeating the conservative candidate, no more centre left split.. This was reflected in exit polls, and was my personal experience with almost everyone I know, particularly the young friends and other relatives of my sons. This was not a normal alteration.

Canadians rejected the type of international military efforts that Harper espoused. Canadians have always been very proud of our participation in UN affairs, and most were angry at Harper's withdrawal in that area.

You are right. Canada is not Camelot. I have been amazed to see more articles in the NYT's in the last week than there have been in total for years. Americans seem interested in how we did it.

You can do it too. Vote for the good guy with the good ideas, and vote a straight ticket that will let those ideas come to fruition.
Dub and his administration IGNORED the Al Qaeda threat from SAUDI terrorists, and almost 4000 people died in New York... Where is that investigation happening?

When a tree is felled the stump and roots decay, clearcut or no.  Erosion is mostly from trail making when done poorly.  Reforestation depends upon the new trees starting before the grasses and other understory are established.  Sometimes this means planting seedlings.
Robespierre has come back to life in the form of Trey Gowdy. They even resemble each other.
Change Parties.  We are way more sane over here. And as a reasonable person, you'd be welcome.

Paul Ryan is the worst kind of politician. He only cares about his own career. He doesn't care how his actions affect others, even in his own party. He certainly doesn't care about how his actions affect the USA or the world.

He is a liar (http://www.runnersworld.com/newswire/paul-ryan-has-not-run-sub-300-marat..., a fool (http://www.cbpp.org/research/the-ryan-budgets-radical-priorities, and disloyal.

He's a silver-spoon-fed, born-on-3rd-base, trust funder (http://www.esquire.com/news-politics/politics/a15319/paul-ryan-family-we....

He's just the kind of person the GOP worships.

Gang mentality, as you have ascribed to the "freedom caucus", is also exemplified by another well known ideology that took power more than 80 years ago, taking advantage of a weakened government but using the legal levers of power.  Eternal vigilance.
Mr. Gowdy, shut down this committee! And take the shame.

"making election of a Republican president more likely than otherwise."  Hmmm. Not with the current cast of characters. There isn't one among them who could win a general election, no matter what Ryan does.

Gemma:

Nonsense. Depending on who the Democrats put up, Bush, Rubio and Kasich could attract enough moderate Democratic and Independent votes to be elected president. It likely will be Bush, regardless of confused projections months before the first primary and caucus; and an election between him and Hillary, from where I'm sitting, would be too close to call right through election day.

The editors may be missing some body language.

First, most of the Republican House majority, while more uniformly conservative than at any time in recent memory – including 1995 – is far more open to compromise than the “Freedom Caucus”; but is sufficiently intimidated by the prospect of seeing primary opponents emerge to their right that they punt when the 40 rise up on their hind legs. Yet this dysfunction has gone on long enough and a lot of those Republicans could be ready for a Moses to lead them out of Egypt. The timing could be good for Ryan.

Then, Ryan is an incremental mover who knows how to co-opt Democratic support by small compromises. He is not one to shy from using such tactics to move legislation; and if he can find that non-Pelosi-dominated coalition of Democrats to reliably support legislation they don’t consider completely outrageous so long as some of their interests are attended to, the Freedom Caucus, with only 40 members, could become isolated.

But Democrats should stand back a bit and consider what that would mean. Ryan is extremely conservative: he simply believes in winning and not merely in waging pyrrhic battles that sound good to constituents but fail. He wouldn’t shut down government, and if he IS elected speaker, two things are likely to happen: Congress will actually start moving, and it won’t be moving left; and damaging actions from the right will cease, making election of a Republican president more likely than otherwise.
I hope Representative Trey Gowdy will tender his resignation.

In the end it will be Kevin McCarthy, who had the good sense to avoid the Faustian wager of  riding herd over this ship of fools, that will be seen to have had the better judgement. It is only Ryan's arrogance that makes him think this job will end in any other way than the ideological purists hanging him out to dry. Keep at it Ryan; you're the golden boy, the Republican's intellectual policy wonk.   Someday you will wonder how it all could have gone so horribly wrong.
